job_title: Project Finance Officer in Washington, DC
pros: CNFA has very great management. All of the teams are very supportive and friendly . It is family oriented, professional and flexible organization
cons: Littel growth opportunities in some departments because of the structure.

review_title: Avoid This Company Until Institutional Changes Are Made
pros:
Good health, dental, and vision insurance package.
More holidays than other companies in the industry, and holidays and sick leave are split.
Opportunity for travel among junior staff.
cons:
HR exists to protect senior management, and makes little to no effort to support mid- and junior-level staff. On at least a dozen occasions during my tenure, CNFA HR made junior staff cry. 
Not a supportive environment for employees with physical disabilities, and very little support available to employees prioritizing mental health .
Commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion seems to be surface level only - employees who expressed concern about DEI were forced onto a committee to fix the issue for the company without any management buy-in. The suggestions of the newly formed DEI committee were disregarded entirely.
Little was done at the start of Covid-19 to ease employees' transition to working from home, or provide support throughout the pandemic. 
Some managers blame project failures on junior staff as well as verbally abuse their subordinates. 
Rate of accrual of sick days should be higher, especially during a pandemic. 
Salaries are low compared to competitors within the industry, and negotiation is distressing and challenging due to blatantly hostile conversations with HR.

pros: Projects focus on interesting issues in agriculture
cons:
This is one of the worst places I have ever worked in terms of office/work culture, professionalism, onboarding/training of new staff, institutional memory, and relationships between colleagues.

My team consisted of people who were unqualified and lied about their experience, technical abilities, as well as language fluency. Little to no effort was made to foster an inclusive or accepting environment in terms of social and friendly relationships amongst employees as well as in terms of diversity, equity, and inclusion,

The only silver lining to my experience at CNFA was learning what NOT to do and how NOT to manage, lead, and supervise others. This company has many red flags and it would be advisable to be aware of them before starting here.

pros:
Flexible working environment culturally diverse 
Autonomy when working
cons:
Lacks humanity for its field office
Limited growth opportunities for field offices

review_title: Agronomy Advisor at CNFA-Rwanda Hinga Weze Activity
pros: Team work spirit, Good pay, very good health insurance to employees
cons: Very big workload, limited professional development training to technical team

review_title: Organization committed to good development and its staff
pros: Mission-driven. Large enough to have strong systems, support and resources in place, and small enough to feel like everyone is valued, and that good ideas at any level can influence the management of CNFA. Also better benefits than most organizations within the industry.
cons: During COVID, as with most organizations I would imagine, it has been challenging to feel connected to everyone outside of the people one works with most frequently

review_title: This is the worst place I have every worked.
pros:
- Talented, and underappreciated, junior staff. 
- Opportunity to travel
- Some nice wellness events.
- More holidays than most companies. 
- If you're good at staying quiet in the face of injustice, you'll do great here.
cons:
Workplace bullying, discrimination, harassment, and abuse -CNFA lacks adequate reporting and those that do report any of the aforementioned are met with retaliation, lack of confidentiality, and the ultimate demise of their reputation at CNFA. I personally witnessed several colleagues reporting ageism, other forms of discrimination and workplace bullying to no avail, to the extreme detriment of their mental health. HR is well aware of the abuse upper-level individuals are inflicting , even stating to me "I was waiting for you to come forward," and yet do nothing. The executive team also turns a blind eye, valuing output more than the people they work with. 

Diversity - Or lack thereof. This is the least diverse development org I've ever worked for. While our competitors had townhalls, released statements, and initiated learning events surrounding the events following the murder of George Floyd, CNFA couldn't even acknowledge what was going on in our own backyard without the pressure from their junior staff. Similarly, there wasn't so much as an email during the insurrection of the Nation's Capital, epitomizing the complete lack of regard the Executive team has for their staff/ staff's mental health. Why would any POC want to work for an org that doesn't value or represent them (check out the diversity of the board/executive team for example).

Lack of transparency - decisions that impact employees are more often than not discussed behind closed doors without any input from staff, particularly junior staff. There aren't any salary scales, and staff are paid according to the head of HR's whim (who quite literally plays favorites).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Excellent benefits, 403b matching, vision, dental, health, flex spending, 3 weeks paid vacation, sick days, federal holidays

Great opportunity for professional growth and to learn new skills. HR is very responsive to employee needs
cons:
Salary was at least $3000 below competitors regardless of non-profit or for-profit status

Not a lot of opportunity for promotion after officer level. CNFA spends a LOT of time training people and then does not compete salary- or promotion-wise, so there’s a high turn over

That excellent opportunity to learn and grow came from being chronically understaffed.

pros: Laid back staff, decent 401 (k) contribution with no vesting period.
cons: The upper management of the company has no idea about what direction they are taking the company in, promotions are based on whether the employee is liked by the senior management.It's a technologically backward company with limited/no use of the current business practices.The salary s below market standards by 20-25%

pros: Great benefits as other reviews note. It seems as if the benefits structure was created for Executive Mgt.  Good 401k.
cons: Not much vision or mission of the organization.  Basically, the goal is to secure USAID contracts. So, if you want to innovate, be a leader in your field, and make an impact that you can connect with around the world this is probably not the best place to work in the development space.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Demanding of your time, but management recognizes employee sacrifices. CEO is friendly and enthusiastic - widely reputed to be a pleasant change from a former CEO.
cons: Can be a little disorganized at times, with too many cooks in the kitchen at the same time on proposal writing.

cons: None. I only left because I had a unique opportunity at graduate school.
